segment.source: In addition to using voice commands within Cortana to access system features, you can also extend Cortana with features and functionality from a background app using voice commands that specify an action or command to execute within the app.
segment.target: In addition to using voice commands within Cortana to access system features, you can also extend Cortana with features and functionality from a background app using voice commands that specify an action or command to execute within the app.

segment.source: Launch a background app with voice commands in Cortana
segment.target: Launch a background app with voice commands in Cortana

segment.source: Activate a background app with voice commands through Cortana
segment.target: Activate a background app with voice commands through Cortana

segment.source: In addition to using voice commands within Cortana to access system features, you can also extend Cortana with features and functionality from your app (as a background task) using voice commands that specify an action or command to execute.
segment.target: In addition to using voice commands within Cortana to access system features, you can also extend Cortana with features and functionality from your app (as a background task) using voice commands that specify an action or command to execute.

segment.source: When an app handles a voice command in the background, it does not take focus.
segment.target: When an app handles a voice command in the background, it does not take focus.

segment.source: Instead, it returns all feedback and results through the Cortana canvas and the Cortana voice.
segment.target: Instead, it returns all feedback and results through the Cortana canvas and the Cortana voice.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.ApplicationModel.VoiceCommands
segment.target: Windows.ApplicationModel.VoiceCommands

segment.source: VCD elements and attributes v1.2
segment.target: VCD elements and attributes v1.2

segment.source: Apps can be activated to the foreground (the app takes focus) or activated in the background (Cortana retains focus), depending on the complexity of the interaction.
segment.target: Apps can be activated to the foreground (the app takes focus) or activated in the background (Cortana retains focus), depending on the complexity of the interaction.

segment.source: For example, voice commands that require additional context or user input (such as sending a message to a specific contact) are best handled in a foreground app, while basic commands (such as listing upcoming trips) can be handled in Cortana through a background app.
segment.target: For example, voice commands that require additional context or user input (such as sending a message to a specific contact) are best handled in a foreground app, while basic commands (such as listing upcoming trips) can be handled in Cortana through a background app.

segment.source: If you want to activate an app to the foreground using voice commands, see Activate a foreground app with voice commands through Cortana.
segment.target: If you want to activate an app to the foreground using voice commands, see Activate a foreground app with voice commands through Cortana.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: A voice command is a single utterance with a specific intent, defined in a Voice Command Definition (VCD) file, directed at an installed app through Cortana.
segment.target: A voice command is a single utterance with a specific intent, defined in a Voice Command Definition (VCD) file, directed at an installed app through Cortana.

segment.source: A VCD file defines one or more voice commands, each with a unique intent.
segment.target: A VCD file defines one or more voice commands, each with a unique intent.

segment.source: A voice command definition can vary in complexity.
segment.target: A voice command definition can vary in complexity.

segment.source: It can support anything from a single, constrained utterance to a collection of more flexible, natural language utterances, all denoting the same intent.
segment.target: It can support anything from a single, constrained utterance to a collection of more flexible, natural language utterances, all denoting the same intent.

segment.source: To demonstrate background app features, we'll use a trip planning and management app named Adventure Works from the Cortana voice command sample.
segment.target: To demonstrate background app features, we'll use a trip planning and management app named Adventure Works from the Cortana voice command sample.

segment.source: Here's an overview of the Adventure Works app integrated with the Cortana canvas.
segment.target: Here's an overview of the Adventure Works app integrated with the Cortana canvas.

segment.source: cortana canvas overview
segment.target: cortana canvas overview

segment.source: To view an Adventure Works trip without Cortana, a user would launch the app and navigate to the Upcoming trips page.
segment.target: To view an Adventure Works trip without Cortana, a user would launch the app and navigate to the Upcoming trips page.

segment.source: Using voice commands through Cortana to launch your app in the background, the user can instead just say, "Adventure Works, when is my trip to Las Vegas?".
segment.target: Using voice commands through Cortana to launch your app in the background, the user can instead just say, "Adventure Works, when is my trip to Las Vegas?".

segment.source: Your app handles the command and Cortana displays results along with your app icon and other app info, if provided.
segment.target: Your app handles the command and Cortana displays results along with your app icon and other app info, if provided.

segment.source: Here's an example of a basic trip query and Cortana result screen that both shows and speaks "Your next trip to Las Vegas is on Friday July 31st, 2015".
segment.target: Here's an example of a basic trip query and Cortana result screen that both shows and speaks "Your next trip to Las Vegas is on Friday July 31st, 2015".

segment.source: a basic query and result screen using the adventure works app in the background
segment.target: a basic query and result screen using the adventure works app in the background

segment.source: These are the basic steps to add voice-command functionality and extend Cortana with background functionality from your app using speech or keyboard input:
segment.target: These are the basic steps to add voice-command functionality and extend Cortana with background functionality from your app using speech or keyboard input:

segment.source: Create an app service (see Windows.ApplicationModel.AppService) that Cortana invokes in the background.
segment.target: Create an app service (see Windows.ApplicationModel.AppService) that Cortana invokes in the background.

segment.source: Create a VCD file.
segment.target: Create a VCD file.

segment.source: This is an XML document that defines all the spoken commands that the user can say to initiate actions or invoke commands when activating your app.
segment.target: This is an XML document that defines all the spoken commands that the user can say to initiate actions or invoke commands when activating your app.

segment.source: See VCD elements and attributes v1.2.
segment.target: See VCD elements and attributes v1.2.

segment.source: Register the command sets in the VCD file when the app is launched.
segment.target: Register the command sets in the VCD file when the app is launched.

segment.source: Handle the background activation of the app service and the execution of the voice command.
segment.target: Handle the background activation of the app service and the execution of the voice command.

segment.source: Display and speak the appropriate feedback to the voice command within Cortana.
segment.target: Display and speak the appropriate feedback to the voice command within Cortana.

segment.source: Prerequisites:
segment.target: Prerequisites:

segment.source: If you're new to developing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps, have a look through these topics to get familiar with the technologies discussed here.
segment.target: If you're new to developing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps, have a look through these topics to get familiar with the technologies discussed here.

segment.source: Create your first app
segment.target: Create your first app

segment.source: Learn about events with Events and routed events overview
segment.target: Learn about events with Events and routed events overview

segment.source: User experience guidelines:
segment.target: User experience guidelines:

segment.source: See Cortana design guidelines for info about how to integrate your app with Cortana and Speech design guidelines for helpful tips on designing a useful and engaging speech-enabled app.
segment.target: See Cortana design guidelines for info about how to integrate your app with Cortana and Speech design guidelines for helpful tips on designing a useful and engaging speech-enabled app.

segment.source: Create a new solution with a primary project in Visual Studio
segment.target: Create a new solution with a primary project in Visual Studio

segment.source: Launch Microsoft Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: Launch Microsoft Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: The Visual Studio 2015 Start page appears.
segment.target: The Visual Studio 2015 Start page appears.

segment.source: On the File menu, select NewProject.
segment.target: On the File menu, select NewProject.

segment.source: The New Project dialog appears.
segment.target: The New Project dialog appears.

segment.source: The left pane of the dialog lets you select the type of templates to display.
segment.target: The left pane of the dialog lets you select the type of templates to display.

segment.source: In the left pane, expand Installed > Templates > Visual C > Windows, then pick the Universal template group.
segment.target: In the left pane, expand Installed > Templates > Visual C > Windows, then pick the Universal template group.

segment.source: The dialog's center pane displays a list of project templates for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: The dialog's center pane displays a list of project templates for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: In the center pane, select the Blank App (Universal Windows) template.
segment.target: In the center pane, select the Blank App (Universal Windows) template.

segment.source: The Blank App template creates a minimal UWP app that compiles and runs, but contains no user-interface controls or data.
segment.target: The Blank App template creates a minimal UWP app that compiles and runs, but contains no user-interface controls or data.

segment.source: You add controls to the app over the course of this tutorial.
segment.target: You add controls to the app over the course of this tutorial.

segment.source: In the Name text box, type your project name.
segment.target: In the Name text box, type your project name.

segment.source: For this example, we use "AdventureWorks".
segment.target: For this example, we use "AdventureWorks".

segment.source: Click OK to create the project.
segment.target: Click OK to create the project.

segment.source: Microsoft Visual Studio creates your project and displays it in the Solution Explorer.
segment.target: Microsoft Visual Studio creates your project and displays it in the Solution Explorer.

segment.source: Add image assets to primary project and specify them in the app manifest
segment.target: Add image assets to primary project and specify them in the app manifest

segment.source: UWP apps can automatically select the most appropriate images based on specific settings and device capabilities (high contrast, effective pixels, locale, and so on).
segment.target: UWP apps can automatically select the most appropriate images based on specific settings and device capabilities (high contrast, effective pixels, locale, and so on).

segment.source: All you need to do is provide the images and ensure you use the appropriate naming convention and folder organization within the app project for the different resource versions.
segment.target: All you need to do is provide the images and ensure you use the appropriate naming convention and folder organization within the app project for the different resource versions.

segment.source: If you don't provide the recommended resource versions, accessibility, localization, and image quality can suffer, depending on the user's preferences, abilities, device type, and location.
segment.target: If you don't provide the recommended resource versions, accessibility, localization, and image quality can suffer, depending on the user's preferences, abilities, device type, and location.

segment.source: For more detail on image resources for high contrast and scale factors, see Guidelines for tile and icon assets.
segment.target: For more detail on image resources for high contrast and scale factors, see Guidelines for tile and icon assets.

segment.source: You name resources using qualifiers.
segment.target: You name resources using qualifiers.

segment.source: Resource qualifiers are folder and filename modifiers that identify the context in which a particular version of a resource should be used.
segment.target: Resource qualifiers are folder and filename modifiers that identify the context in which a particular version of a resource should be used.

segment.source: The standard naming convention is .
segment.target: The standard naming convention is .

segment.source: For example, , which can be referred to in code using just the root folder and the filename: .
segment.target: For example, , which can be referred to in code using just the root folder and the filename: .

segment.source: See How to name resources using qualifiers.
segment.target: See How to name resources using qualifiers.

segment.source: We recommend that you mark the default language on string resource files (such as ) and the default scale factor on images (such as ), even if you do not currently plan to provide localized or multiple resolution resources.
segment.target: We recommend that you mark the default language on string resource files (such as ) and the default scale factor on images (such as ), even if you do not currently plan to provide localized or multiple resolution resources.

segment.source: However, at a minimum, we recommend that you provide assets for 100, 200, and 400 scale factors.
segment.target: However, at a minimum, we recommend that you provide assets for 100, 200, and 400 scale factors.

segment.source: *Important
segment.target: *Important

segment.source: The app icon used in the title area of the Cortana canvas is the Square44x44Logo icon specified in the "Package.appxmanifest" file.
segment.target: The app icon used in the title area of the Cortana canvas is the Square44x44Logo icon specified in the "Package.appxmanifest" file.

segment.source: You can also specify an icon for each entry in the content area of the Cortana canvas.
segment.target: You can also specify an icon for each entry in the content area of the Cortana canvas.

segment.source: Valid image sizes for the results icons are:
segment.target: Valid image sizes for the results icons are:

segment.source: 68w x 68h
segment.target: 68w x 68h

segment.source: 68w x 92h
segment.target: 68w x 92h

segment.source: The content tile is not validated until a VoiceCommandResponse is passed to the VoiceCommandServiceConnection.
segment.target: The content tile is not validated until a VoiceCommandResponse is passed to the VoiceCommandServiceConnection.

segment.source: If you pass a VoiceCommandResponse object to Cortana that contains a content tile with an image that does not adhere to these size ratios, an exception can occur.
segment.target: If you pass a VoiceCommandResponse object to Cortana that contains a content tile with an image that does not adhere to these size ratios, an exception can occur.

segment.source: In this example from the Adventure Works app (VoiceCommandServiceAdventureWorksVoiceCommandService.cs), we specify a simple grey square ("GreyTile.png") on the VoiceCommandContentTile using the TitleWith68x68IconAndText tile template.
segment.target: In this example from the Adventure Works app (VoiceCommandServiceAdventureWorksVoiceCommandService.cs), we specify a simple grey square ("GreyTile.png") on the VoiceCommandContentTile using the TitleWith68x68IconAndText tile template.

segment.source: The logo variants are located in VoiceCommandServiceImages, and are retrieved using the GetFileFromApplicationUriAsync method.
segment.target: The logo variants are located in VoiceCommandServiceImages, and are retrieved using the GetFileFromApplicationUriAsync method.

segment.source: Create an app service project
segment.target: Create an app service project

segment.source: Right-click your Solution name, select New > Project.
segment.target: Right-click your Solution name, select New > Project.

segment.source: Under Installed > Templates > Visual C# > Windows > Universal, select Windows Runtime Component.
segment.target: Under Installed > Templates > Visual C# > Windows > Universal, select Windows Runtime Component.

segment.source: This is the component that implements the app service (Windows.ApplicationModel.AppService).
segment.target: This is the component that implements the app service (Windows.ApplicationModel.AppService).

segment.source: Type a name for the project (for example, "VoiceCommandService") and click OK.
segment.target: Type a name for the project (for example, "VoiceCommandService") and click OK.

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, select the "VoiceCommandService" project and rename the "Class1.cs" file generated by Visual Studio.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, select the "VoiceCommandService" project and rename the "Class1.cs" file generated by Visual Studio.

segment.source: For the Adventure Works example we use "AdventureWorksVoiceCommandService.cs".
segment.target: For the Adventure Works example we use "AdventureWorksVoiceCommandService.cs".

segment.source: Click Yes when asked if you want to rename all occurrences of "Class1.cs".
segment.target: Click Yes when asked if you want to rename all occurrences of "Class1.cs".

segment.source: In the "AdventureWorksVoiceCommandService.cs" file:
segment.target: In the "AdventureWorksVoiceCommandService.cs" file:

segment.source: Add the following using directive.
segment.target: Add the following using directive.

segment.source: When you create a new project, the project name is used as the default root namespace in all files.
segment.target: When you create a new project, the project name is used as the default root namespace in all files.

segment.source: Rename the namespace to nest the app service code under the primary project.
segment.target: Rename the namespace to nest the app service code under the primary project.

segment.source: For example, .
segment.target: For example, .

segment.source: Right click the app service project name in Solution Explorer and select Properties.
segment.target: Right click the app service project name in Solution Explorer and select Properties.

segment.source: On the Library tab, update the Default namespace field with this same value (for this example, "AdventureWorks.VoiceCommands").
segment.target: On the Library tab, update the Default namespace field with this same value (for this example, "AdventureWorks.VoiceCommands").

segment.source: Create a new class that implements the IBackgroundTask interface.
segment.target: Create a new class that implements the IBackgroundTask interface.

segment.source: This class requires a Run method, which is the entry point when Cortana recognizes the voice command.
segment.target: This class requires a Run method, which is the entry point when Cortana recognizes the voice command.

segment.source: Here's a basic background task class from the Adventure Works app.
segment.target: Here's a basic background task class from the Adventure Works app.

segment.source: We'll fill in more detail later.
segment.target: We'll fill in more detail later.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The background task class itself, and all other classes in the background task project, need to be sealed public classes.
segment.target: The background task class itself, and all other classes in the background task project, need to be sealed public classes.

segment.source: Declare your background task as an AppService in the app manifest.
segment.target: Declare your background task as an AppService in the app manifest.

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, right click the "Package.appxmanifest" file and select View Code.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, right click the "Package.appxmanifest" file and select View Code.

segment.source: Find the Application element.
segment.target: Find the Application element.

segment.source: Add an Extensions element to the Application element.
segment.target: Add an Extensions element to the Application element.

segment.source: Add a uap:Extension element to the Extensions element.
segment.target: Add a uap:Extension element to the Extensions element.

segment.source: Add a Category attribute to the uap:Extension element and set the value of the Category attribute to "windows.appService".
segment.target: Add a Category attribute to the uap:Extension element and set the value of the Category attribute to "windows.appService".

segment.source: Add an EntryPoint attribute to the uap:Extension element and set the value of the EntryPoint attribute to the name of the class that implements IBackgroundTask, in this case "AdventureWorks.VoiceCommands.AdventureWorksVoiceCommandService".
segment.target: Add an EntryPoint attribute to the uap:Extension element and set the value of the EntryPoint attribute to the name of the class that implements IBackgroundTask, in this case "AdventureWorks.VoiceCommands.AdventureWorksVoiceCommandService".

segment.source: Add a uap:AppService element to the uap:Extension element.
segment.target: Add a uap:AppService element to the uap:Extension element.

segment.source: Add a Name attribute to the uap:AppService element and set the value of the Name attribute to a name for the app service, in this case "AdventureWorksVoiceCommandService".
segment.target: Add a Name attribute to the uap:AppService element and set the value of the Name attribute to a name for the app service, in this case "AdventureWorksVoiceCommandService".

segment.source: Add a second uap:Extension element to Extensions.
segment.target: Add a second uap:Extension element to Extensions.

segment.source: Add a Category attribute to this uap:Extension element and set the value of the Category attribute to "windows.personalAssistantLaunch".
segment.target: Add a Category attribute to this uap:Extension element and set the value of the Category attribute to "windows.personalAssistantLaunch".

segment.source: Here's the manifest from the Adventure Works app:
segment.target: Here's the manifest from the Adventure Works app:

segment.source: Add this app service project as a reference in the primary project.
segment.target: Add this app service project as a reference in the primary project.

segment.source: Right click References.
segment.target: Right click References.

segment.source: Select Add Reference...
segment.target: Select Add Reference...

segment.source: In the Reference Manager dialog, expand Projects and select the app service project.
segment.target: In the Reference Manager dialog, expand Projects and select the app service project.

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: Create a VCD file
segment.target: Create a VCD file

segment.source: In Visual Studio, right-click your primary project name, select Add > New Item.
segment.target: In Visual Studio, right-click your primary project name, select Add > New Item.

segment.source: Add an XML File.
segment.target: Add an XML File.

segment.source: Type a name for the VCD file (for this example, "AdventureWorksCommands.xml"), and click Add.
segment.target: Type a name for the VCD file (for this example, "AdventureWorksCommands.xml"), and click Add.

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, select the VCD file.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, select the VCD file.

segment.source: In the Properties window, set Build action to Content, and then set Copy to output directory to Copy if newer.
segment.target: In the Properties window, set Build action to Content, and then set Copy to output directory to Copy if newer.

segment.source: Edit the VCD file
segment.target: Edit the VCD file

segment.source: Add a VoiceCommands element with an xmlns attribute pointing to .
segment.target: Add a VoiceCommands element with an xmlns attribute pointing to .

segment.source: For each language supported by your app, create a CommandSet element that contains the voice commands supported by your app.
segment.target: For each language supported by your app, create a CommandSet element that contains the voice commands supported by your app.

segment.source: You can declare multiple CommandSet elements, each with a different xml:lang attribute so your app to be used in different markets.
segment.target: You can declare multiple CommandSet elements, each with a different xml:lang attribute so your app to be used in different markets.

segment.source: For example, an app for the United States might have a CommandSet for English and a CommandSet for Spanish.
segment.target: For example, an app for the United States might have a CommandSet for English and a CommandSet for Spanish.

segment.source: Caution
segment.target: Caution

segment.source: To activate an app and initiate an action using a voice command, the app must register a VCD file that contains a CommandSet with a language that matches the speech language selected by the user for their device.
segment.target: To activate an app and initiate an action using a voice command, the app must register a VCD file that contains a CommandSet with a language that matches the speech language selected by the user for their device.

segment.source: The speech language is located in Settings > System > Speech > Speech Language.
segment.target: The speech language is located in Settings > System > Speech > Speech Language.

segment.source: Add a Command element for each command you want to support.
segment.target: Add a Command element for each command you want to support.

segment.source: Each Command declared in a VCD file must include this information:
segment.target: Each Command declared in a VCD file must include this information:

segment.source: A Name attribute that your application uses to identify the voice command at runtime.
segment.target: A Name attribute that your application uses to identify the voice command at runtime.

segment.source: An Example element that contains a phrase describing how a user can invoke the command.
segment.target: An Example element that contains a phrase describing how a user can invoke the command.

segment.source: Cortana shows this example when the user says "What can I say?", "Help", or they tap See more.
segment.target: Cortana shows this example when the user says "What can I say?", "Help", or they tap See more.

segment.source: A ListenFor element that contains the words or phrases that your app recognizes as a command.
segment.target: A ListenFor element that contains the words or phrases that your app recognizes as a command.

segment.source: Each ListenFor element can contain references to one or more PhraseList elements that contain specific words relevant to the command.
segment.target: Each ListenFor element can contain references to one or more PhraseList elements that contain specific words relevant to the command.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: ListenFor elements cannot be programmatically modified.
segment.target: ListenFor elements cannot be programmatically modified.

segment.source: However, PhraseList elements associated with ListenFor elements can be programmatically modified.
segment.target: However, PhraseList elements associated with ListenFor elements can be programmatically modified.

segment.source: Applications should modify the content of the PhraseList at runtime based on the data set generated as the user uses the app.
segment.target: Applications should modify the content of the PhraseList at runtime based on the data set generated as the user uses the app.

segment.source: See Dynamically modify Voice Command Definition (VCD) phrase lists.
segment.target: See Dynamically modify Voice Command Definition (VCD) phrase lists.

segment.source: A Feedback element that contains the text for Cortana to display and speak as the application is launched.
segment.target: A Feedback element that contains the text for Cortana to display and speak as the application is launched.

segment.source: A Navigate element indicates that the voice command activates the app to the foreground.
segment.target: A Navigate element indicates that the voice command activates the app to the foreground.

segment.source: In this example, the command is a foreground task.
segment.target: In this example, the command is a foreground task.

segment.source: A VoiceCommandService element indicates that the voice command activates the app in the background.
segment.target: A VoiceCommandService element indicates that the voice command activates the app in the background.

segment.source: The value of the Target attribute of this element should match the value of the Name attribute of the uap:AppService element in the package.appxmanifest file.
segment.target: The value of the Target attribute of this element should match the value of the Name attribute of the uap:AppService element in the package.appxmanifest file.

segment.source: In this example, the and commands are background tasks that specify the name of the app service as "AdventureWorksVoiceCommandService".
segment.target: In this example, the and commands are background tasks that specify the name of the app service as "AdventureWorksVoiceCommandService".

segment.source: For more detail, see the VCD elements and attributes v1.2 reference.
segment.target: For more detail, see the VCD elements and attributes v1.2 reference.

segment.source: Here's a portion of the VCD file that defines the en-us voice commands for the Adventure Works app.
segment.target: Here's a portion of the VCD file that defines the en-us voice commands for the Adventure Works app.

segment.source: Install the VCD commands
segment.target: Install the VCD commands

segment.source: Your app must run once to install the VCD.
segment.target: Your app must run once to install the VCD.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Voice command data is not preserved across app installations.
segment.target: Voice command data is not preserved across app installations.

segment.source: To ensure the voice command data for your app remains intact, consider initializing your VCD file each time your app is launched or activated, or maintain a setting that indicates if the VCD is currently installed.
segment.target: To ensure the voice command data for your app remains intact, consider initializing your VCD file each time your app is launched or activated, or maintain a setting that indicates if the VCD is currently installed.

segment.source: In the "app.xaml.cs" file:
segment.target: In the "app.xaml.cs" file:

segment.source: Add the following using directive:
segment.target: Add the following using directive:

segment.source: Mark the "OnLaunched" method with the async modifier.
segment.target: Mark the "OnLaunched" method with the async modifier.

segment.source: Call InstallCommandDefinitionsFromStorageFileAsync in the OnLaunched handler to register the voice commands that the system should recognize.
segment.target: Call InstallCommandDefinitionsFromStorageFileAsync in the OnLaunched handler to register the voice commands that the system should recognize.

segment.source: In the Adventure Works sample, we first define a StorageFile object.
segment.target: In the Adventure Works sample, we first define a StorageFile object.

segment.source: We then call GetFileAsync to initialize it with our "AdventureWorksCommands.xml" file.
segment.target: We then call GetFileAsync to initialize it with our "AdventureWorksCommands.xml" file.

segment.source: This StorageFile object is then passed to InstallCommandDefinitionsFromStorageFileAsync.
segment.target: This StorageFile object is then passed to InstallCommandDefinitionsFromStorageFileAsync.

segment.source: Handle activation
segment.target: Handle activation

segment.source: Specify how your app responds to subsequent voice command activations (after it has been launched at least once and the voice command sets have been installed).
segment.target: Specify how your app responds to subsequent voice command activations (after it has been launched at least once and the voice command sets have been installed).

segment.source: Confirm that your app was activated by a voice command.
segment.target: Confirm that your app was activated by a voice command.

segment.source: Override the Application.OnActivated event and check whether IActivatedEventArgs.Kind is VoiceCommand.
segment.target: Override the Application.OnActivated event and check whether IActivatedEventArgs.Kind is VoiceCommand.

segment.source: Determine the name of the command and what was spoken.
segment.target: Determine the name of the command and what was spoken.

segment.source: Get a reference to a VoiceCommandActivatedEventArgs object from the IActivatedEventArgs and query the Result property for a SpeechRecognitionResult object.
segment.target: Get a reference to a VoiceCommandActivatedEventArgs object from the IActivatedEventArgs and query the Result property for a SpeechRecognitionResult object.

segment.source: To determine what the user said, check the value of Text or the semantic properties of the recognized phrase in the SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation dictionary.
segment.target: To determine what the user said, check the value of Text or the semantic properties of the recognized phrase in the SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation dictionary.

segment.source: Take the appropriate action in your app, such as navigating to the desired page.
segment.target: Take the appropriate action in your app, such as navigating to the desired page.

segment.source: For this example, we refer back to the VCD in Step 3: Edit the VCD file.
segment.target: For this example, we refer back to the VCD in Step 3: Edit the VCD file.

segment.source: Once we get the speech-recognition result for the voice command, we get the command name from the first value in the RulePath array.
segment.target: Once we get the speech-recognition result for the voice command, we get the command name from the first value in the RulePath array.

segment.source: As the VCD file defined more than one possible voice command, we need to compare the value against the command names in the VCD and take the appropriate action.
segment.target: As the VCD file defined more than one possible voice command, we need to compare the value against the command names in the VCD and take the appropriate action.

segment.source: The most common action an application can take is to navigate to a page with content relevant to the context of the voice command.
segment.target: The most common action an application can take is to navigate to a page with content relevant to the context of the voice command.

segment.source: For this example, we navigate to a TripPage page and pass in the value of the voice command, how the command was input, and the recognized "destination" phrase (if applicable).
segment.target: For this example, we navigate to a TripPage page and pass in the value of the voice command, how the command was input, and the recognized "destination" phrase (if applicable).

segment.source: Alternatively, the app could send a navigation parameter to the SpeechRecognitionResult when navigating to the page.
segment.target: Alternatively, the app could send a navigation parameter to the SpeechRecognitionResult when navigating to the page.

segment.source: You can find out whether the voice command that launched your app was actually spoken, or whether it was typed in as text, from the SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation.Properties dictionary using the commandMode key.
segment.target: You can find out whether the voice command that launched your app was actually spoken, or whether it was typed in as text, from the SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation.Properties dictionary using the commandMode key.

segment.source: The value of that key will be either "voice" or "text".
segment.target: The value of that key will be either "voice" or "text".

segment.source: If the value of the key is "voice", consider using speech synthesis (Windows.Media.SpeechSynthesis) in your app to provide the user with spoken feedback.
segment.target: If the value of the key is "voice", consider using speech synthesis (Windows.Media.SpeechSynthesis) in your app to provide the user with spoken feedback.

segment.source: Use the SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation.Properties to find out the content spoken in the PhraseList or PhraseTopic constraints of a ListenFor element.
segment.target: Use the SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation.Properties to find out the content spoken in the PhraseList or PhraseTopic constraints of a ListenFor element.

segment.source: The dictionary key is the value of the Label attribute of the PhraseList or PhraseTopic element.
segment.target: The dictionary key is the value of the Label attribute of the PhraseList or PhraseTopic element.

segment.source: Here, we show how to access the value of {destination} phrase.
segment.target: Here, we show how to access the value of {destination} phrase.

segment.source: Handle the voice command in the app service
segment.target: Handle the voice command in the app service

segment.source: Process the voice command in the app service.
segment.target: Process the voice command in the app service.

segment.source: Add the following using directives to your voice command service file, "AdventureWorksVoiceCommandService.cs" for this example.
segment.target: Add the following using directives to your voice command service file, "AdventureWorksVoiceCommandService.cs" for this example.

segment.source: Take a service deferral so your app service is not terminated while handling the voice command.
segment.target: Take a service deferral so your app service is not terminated while handling the voice command.

segment.source: Confirm that your background task is running as an app service activated by a voice command.
segment.target: Confirm that your background task is running as an app service activated by a voice command.

segment.source: Cast the IBackgroundTaskInstance.TriggerDetails to Windows.ApplicationModel.AppService.AppServiceTriggerDetails.
segment.target: Cast the IBackgroundTaskInstance.TriggerDetails to Windows.ApplicationModel.AppService.AppServiceTriggerDetails.

segment.source: Check that IBackgroundTaskInstance.TriggerDetails.Name is the name of the app service in the "Package.appxmanifest" file.
segment.target: Check that IBackgroundTaskInstance.TriggerDetails.Name is the name of the app service in the "Package.appxmanifest" file.

segment.source: Use IBackgroundTaskInstance.TriggerDetails to create a VoiceCommandServiceConnection to Cortana to retrieve the voice command.
segment.target: Use IBackgroundTaskInstance.TriggerDetails to create a VoiceCommandServiceConnection to Cortana to retrieve the voice command.

segment.source: Register an event handler for VoiceCommandServiceConnection.VoiceCommandCompleted to receive notification when the app service is closed due to a user cancellation.
segment.target: Register an event handler for VoiceCommandServiceConnection.VoiceCommandCompleted to receive notification when the app service is closed due to a user cancellation.

segment.source: Register an event handler for the IBackgroundTaskInstance.Canceled to receive notification when the app service is closed due to an unexpected failure.
segment.target: Register an event handler for the IBackgroundTaskInstance.Canceled to receive notification when the app service is closed due to an unexpected failure.

segment.source: Determine the name of the command and what was spoken.
segment.target: Determine the name of the command and what was spoken.

segment.source: Use the VoiceCommand.CommandName property to determine the name of the voice command.
segment.target: Use the VoiceCommand.CommandName property to determine the name of the voice command.

segment.source: To determine what the user said, check the value of Text or the semantic properties of the recognized phrase in the SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation dictionary.
segment.target: To determine what the user said, check the value of Text or the semantic properties of the recognized phrase in the SpeechRecognitionSemanticInterpretation dictionary.

segment.source: Take the appropriate action in your app service.
segment.target: Take the appropriate action in your app service.

segment.source: Display and speak the feedback to the voice command with Cortana.
segment.target: Display and speak the feedback to the voice command with Cortana.

segment.source: Determine the strings that you want Cortana to display and speak to the user in response to the voice command and create a VoiceCommandResponse object.
segment.target: Determine the strings that you want Cortana to display and speak to the user in response to the voice command and create a VoiceCommandResponse object.

segment.source: For guidance on how to select the feedback strings that Cortana shows and speaks, see Cortana design guidelines.
segment.target: For guidance on how to select the feedback strings that Cortana shows and speaks, see Cortana design guidelines.

segment.source: Use the VoiceCommandServiceConnection instance to report progress or completion to Cortana by calling ReportProgressAsync or ReportSuccessAsync with the VoiceCommandServiceConnection object.
segment.target: Use the VoiceCommandServiceConnection instance to report progress or completion to Cortana by calling ReportProgressAsync or ReportSuccessAsync with the VoiceCommandServiceConnection object.

segment.source: For this example, we refer back to the VCD in Step 3: Edit the VCD file.
segment.target: For this example, we refer back to the VCD in Step 3: Edit the VCD file.

segment.source: Once activated, the app service has .5 seconds to call ReportSuccessAsync.
segment.target: Once activated, the app service has .5 seconds to call ReportSuccessAsync.

segment.source: Cortana uses the data provided by the app to show and say the feedback specified in the VCD file.
segment.target: Cortana uses the data provided by the app to show and say the feedback specified in the VCD file.

segment.source: If the app takes longer than .5 seconds to make the call, Cortana inserts a hand-off screen, as shown here.
segment.target: If the app takes longer than .5 seconds to make the call, Cortana inserts a hand-off screen, as shown here.

segment.source: Cortana displays the hand-off screen until the application calls ReportSuccessAsync, or for up to 5 seconds.
segment.target: Cortana displays the hand-off screen until the application calls ReportSuccessAsync, or for up to 5 seconds.

segment.source: If the app service doesn’t call ReportSuccessAsync, or any of the VoiceCommandServiceConnection methods that provide Cortana with information, the user receives an error message and the app service is cancelled.
segment.target: If the app service doesn’t call ReportSuccessAsync, or any of the VoiceCommandServiceConnection methods that provide Cortana with information, the user receives an error message and the app service is cancelled.

segment.source: a basic query with progress and result screens using the adventure works app in the background
segment.target: a basic query with progress and result screens using the adventure works app in the background
